ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A deeper understanding of isiZulu cultural and social norms as well as a conversational level of proficiency.
I learned far more Zulu and greatly improved my vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very hands on and interactive course. It would help to have more recorded information to look back on in studying.

Sandra is a great teacher and spends as much time teaching you about the rich culture of the Zulu people as she does going over grammar rules. Weaknesses are negligible and more than worth it for the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely would for anyone interested in getting in touch with their African roots or even interested in doing aid or NGO work in Africa to get a deeper understanding and knowledge of the people they would be working with.
Yes, absolutely if the student if deciding between African languages.
